intro: Sarcoglyphis potamophila, commonly known as the river sandwort, is a flowering plant belonging to the family Montiaceae. It is native to regions of southern Europe and western Asia, typically growing in arid or semi-arid environments. The plant is characterized by its succulent, fleshy leaves and small, inconspicuous flowers that are often clustered in dense inflorescences. It has a shallow root system adapted to nutrient-poor soils and can tolerate periods of drought. Due to its specialized habitat requirements, it is considered a rare and endangered species in many parts of its range.
